'''''Omphalotus olivascens''''', commonly known as the '''western jack-o'-lantern mushroom''', is an orange to brown-colored gilled [[mushroom]] native to [[California]] and [[Mexico]].

==Taxonomy==
The fungus was [[species description|described]] as new to science in 1976 by American mycologists [[Howard E. Bigelow]], [[Orson K. Miller, Jr.]], and [[Harry D. Thiers]].<ref name="Bigelow 1976"/> A subspecies with blue [[trama (mycology)|flesh]], ''O. olivascens'' var. ''indigo'', was described growing on [[Quercus agrifolia|live oak]] in [[Baja California]], Mexico.<ref name="Moreno 1993"/>

Several ''Omphalotus'' species with similar bioluminescent properties occur worldwide, all of which are presumed poisonous. The best known are the North American jack o'lantern mushroom (''[[Omphalotus olearius|O. olearius]]'') and the ''tsukiyotake'' (''[[Omphalotus japonicus|O. japonicus]]'' (Kawam.) Kirchm. & O.K. Mill. (formerly known as ''Lampteromyces japonicus'' (Kawam.) Sing.), found in Japan and eastern Asia. [[molecular phylogenetics|Molecular]] analysis shows the jack-o'-Lantern to be most closely related the ghost fungus ''[[Omphalotus nidiformis]]''.<ref name="Kirchmair 2004"/> Miller notes that the colours and shades of the ghost fungus most closely resemble this species.<ref name="Miller 1994"/>

==Description==
To an untrained eye, ''O. olivascens'' appears similar to some [[Cantharellus|chanterelle]]s, but unlike the chanterelle, the jack-o'-lantern mushroom has [[Lamella (mycology)|true gill]]s (rather than ridges) and it can have olive coloration that chanterelles lack; also, ''Omphalotus'' species are [[Saprotrophic nutrition|saprotrophic]], grow directly on wood, and are [[bioluminescence|bioluminescent]].<ref name=myko/>

==Ecology==
A [[Saprotroph|saprobe]] or [[Parasitism|parasite]], ''O. nidiformis'' is nonspecific in its needs and is compatible with a wide variety of [[host (biology)|hosts]].

''Omphalotus'' species cause a [[Wood-decay fungus#White rot|white rot]] by breaking down [[lignin]] in their tree hosts.<ref name="Kirchmair 2004"/>

==Biochemistry==
The jack o'lantern mushroom is [[poisonous mushroom|poisonous]]; while not lethal, consuming this mushroom leads to very severe [[cramp]]s, [[vomiting]], and [[diarrhea]].<ref name=myko/>

The toxic ingredient of many species of ''Omphalotus'' is a [[sesquiterpene]] compound known as [[illudin]] S.<ref name="Benjamin 1995"/> This, along with illudin M, have been identified in ''O. nidiformis''. The two illudins are common to the genus ''Omphalotus'' and not found in any other basidiomycete mushroom.<ref name="Kirchmair 1999"/>

==See also==
*[[List of bioluminescent fungi]]
